title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Demo
In this workshop, we will do the following:

Set up Git on RStudio
Connect RStudio to GitHub
Connect an existing R Project to GitHub (‚ÄúR First‚Äù)

Make changes locally and on GitHub, and sync them

Clone a GitHub repository to R Studio (‚ÄúGitHub First‚Äù)

Make changes locally and on GitHub, and sync them

Create READMEs

Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.1: Sign up for a GitHub account

I‚Äôd recommend using your personal email, not a student email.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.2 Install Git

Windows:

Open Command Prompt and type where git . If you get an error, continue:
Install Git for Windows (https://gitforwindows.org/)
When asked about ‚ÄúAdjusting your PATH environment‚Äù, make sure to select ‚ÄúGit from the command line and also from 3rd-party software‚Äù. Otherwise, keep the defaults.

Mac OS:

On the Terminal (Mac) type which git . If you get an error, continue:
Install XCode Command Line Tools by opening Terminal and typing xcode-select --install (more info here)
In Terminal, enter git config. Click install.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.3: Configure Git in R

Within the Terminal (Mac) or Shell (Windows) within RStudio (Tools > Terminal/Shell) do

git config --global user.name "your_github_username"
git config --global user.email "your_email_you_used_for_github@example.com"


(If you are having issues, you could use the usethis package in R. See here.)

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.4: Configure Your Personal Access Token (PAT)

Option 1: Go to to https://github.com/settings/tokens and click ‚ÄúGenerate token‚Äù.

Choose Classic Token
Describe the token‚Äôs purpose in the Note field, e.g.¬†‚Äúpersonal-macbook‚Äù or ‚ÄúStat545Installation‚Äù
Select ‚Äúrepo‚Äù, ‚Äúuser‚Äù, and ‚Äúworkflow‚Äù for scopes
Set an expiry date (can regenerate tokens later)
Save this token somewhere so you can use it again later, such as a password manager

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.4: Configure Your Personal Access Token (PAT) (cont‚Äôd)

Option 2: From R, execute usethis::create_github_token() in the Console (you may have to install the usethis package first by first running install.packages("usethis")).

Describe the token‚Äôs purpose in the Note field
Set an expiry date (can regenerate tokens later)
Save this token somewhere so you can use it again later, such as a password manager

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 1: Set Up
Step 1.4: Configure Your Personal Access Token (PAT) (cont‚Äôd)
Regardless of how you generated your PAT, you now need to:

Run install.packages("gitcreds") in the Console
Run gitcreds::gitcreds_set() and enter the PAT that you just made when prompted

Note: the password will not show up when pasted! Paste once and press enter.

section: Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
text:
Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
There are two ways that we can connect GitHub and R Projects. The first way we will show is the ‚ÄúR First‚Äù approach (i.e., starting with an R Project and creating a repository for it).
In Part 5, we will do the opposite and start with a GitHub repository and create a local version of it.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
text:
Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
Step 2.1: Initialize Git

Load in the usethis package by calling library(usethis) in the Console.
Then, run use_git().
When asked to commit changes, select the option that means yes. Restart RStudio if needed.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
text:
Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
You should now see a ‚ÄúGit‚Äù pane by your Environment/History/Connections.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
text:
Part 2: Connect GitHub to an Existing R Project
Step 2.2: Create a GitHub Repository for an Existing Project

Run library(usethis) in the Console
Then, in the Console run use_github().
A new repository on your GitHub account with the same name as your R Project should be created! Head to your GitHub account to check it out.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer
text:
Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer
To use Git, we should first understand the primary states that files can be in. These are:

Modified: you‚Äôve changed something in the files, but Git hasn‚Äôt accounted for them yet.
Staged: Git has tracked the changes you‚Äôve made, but they haven‚Äôt been accounted for in the latest snapshot of your work.
Committed: the changes you‚Äôve made have been stored and updated as the latest snapshot of your project.

After changes are committed locally (on your computer), we can push them to a GitHub repository. This sends the changes and updates the most recent version of your project on GitHub.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer
text:
Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer
Step 3.1: Make some local changes

Edit and save the changes you make to any file in your repository

Do you have a README file yet? If not, create a new Markdown (not RMarkdown) document named README.md. Use markdown syntax to create a header that contains your repository name and a brief description in plain text.
The README file will show up on the home page of your repository on GitHub!

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer
text:
Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer
Step 3.2: Stage Files

Option 1 (Using the Git Pane)

Select the files you want to stage by selecting them.
You will see symbols beside them - ‚ÄúA‚Äù stands for ‚ÄúAdded‚Äù and ‚ÄúM‚Äù stands for ‚Äúmodified‚Äù. If you were to delete a file, you would see a red ‚ÄúD‚Äù.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!

text:
Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer
Step 3.2: Stage Files (cont‚Äôd)

Option 2 (Using the Terminal)

Run git add .. This will stage all of your modified files
You can also just name the files you want to commit instead of using .

text:
Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer
Step 3.3: Commit Changes (save a snapshot of your work!)

Option 1 (Using the Git Pane)

Click the Commit button.
Add a message explaining the changes
Click Commit. Close this pop-up.

section: Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer

Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer
Step 3.3: Commit Changes (save a snapshot of your work, cont‚Äôd)

Option 2 (Using the Terminal)

Run git commit -m "[desciption]" where [description] is a brief summary of the changes.

section: Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer

Step 3.4: Push the Changes to GitHub

Option 1 (Using the Git Pane)

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
section: Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer
text:
Part 3: Sync Changes from your Computer
Step 3.4: Push the Changes to GitHub (cont‚Äôd)

Option 2 (Using the Terminal)

Run git push origin <branchname> in the Terminal

<branchname> is typically main or master. You find the branch name in the Git pane or by using git status
In my example, I would run git push origin main

Part 4: Pull Changes from GitHub
Perhaps you made a change directly on GitHub, or a collaborator pushed changes to Github
These changes are not automatically shown on your local version of your R Project
You need to pull these changes from GitHub to your local version

Option 1 (Using the Git Pane)

Click the Push button

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 5: Cloning
‚ÄúCloning‚Äù refers to the process of taking an existing repository on GitHub and making a copy on your local computer.
Some tutorials will refer to this as a ‚ÄúGitHub First‚Äù approach to syncing your changes to GitHub.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 5: Cloning
Step 5.1: Copy link to repository

Navigate to the repository you want to clone on GitHub.
Clicking the green ‚ÄúCode‚Äù button to copy the address of the repository.

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 5: Cloning
Step 5.2: Clone the Repository

In RStudio, go to ‚ÄúFile > New Project‚Äù
Click on ‚ÄúVersion Control: Checkout a project from a version control repository‚Äù
Click on ‚ÄúGit: Clone a project from a repository‚Äù
Fill in the details:

URL: use the HTTPS address (from Step 5.1)
Create as a subdirectory of: Browse to where you would like to save this repository on your machine (creates a new folder in the location you select)

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 5: Cloning
Now you have a local version of this project!
If you have permission to, you can push and pull the same as in Part 4!

title: Sync your R Projects to GitHub with Confidence!
text:
Part 5: Cloning
Side note:

You can clone any public project, however you need to be added as a collaborator to push those changes to GitHub.
If you‚Äôd like to play around with existing repositories, you could ‚ÄúFork‚Äù it. A fork is a copy of a repository. Forking a repository allows you to freely experiment with changes without affecting the original project. More info here: https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/working-with-forks/fork-a-repo.

title: SSC Virtual Skills Workshop
text:
In this workshop, we will learn how to set up Git on RStudio, and connect our projects to GitHub confidently. Specifically, we will learn how to:

Initialize Git in RStudio,
Connect our R Projects with Git
Synchronize our local projects to GitHub (R project first)
Clone a project that exists on GitHub to RStudio (GitHub first)
Stage, Commit, and Push local changes using command line or RStudio‚Äôs built in Git panel, and
Pull changes from GitHub to your local project.

This workshop was designed for R coders with no prior experience with Git‚Äôs version control system.
The link to register can be found here.

About the Speaker
Dr.¬†Grace Tompkins is an Assistant Professor of Teaching at the University of British Columbia and a recent PhD graduate in Biostatistics from the University of Waterloo. Her teaching focuses on building confidence in statistics and data science by creating inclusive and supportive learning environments. Outside of the classroom, Grace shares free educational content on her YouTube channel (@proftompkins) for students and the broader statistics and data science community.
